page.title: 05Craigie Clips- Part 1.
page.content: We visited{Mr.Darling}whose family had a{grocer's shop}here from 1913. He told us that in the nineteenth century {Western District (Craigie)}was a rail- way village. Small houses for large families were built near the engine sheds and lines, for{railway workers. There used to be two bakeries, chemists, dairies, cobblers and many other shops. On{market days}cattle came in on trains and little, local boys with big sticks, liked to 'help' the{drovers}take them along{cobbled streets to the market behind our school.Gardens thrived! From a{horse and cart,}children took milk in{churns}to people's doors and poured the amount needed into jugs. Parents thought highly of{discipline, and although strictly brought up the children were happy and respected adults and the{law.
